How exactly do those subtitle files work?
Can't you make a dummy video file or rename/convert the normal episodes to match the file?
If the subs can't be advanced/delayed within the player, you might have to add a few seconds of nothing at the beginning of the video to make it sync.

If you can make it work on a completely black video, OCR technology has advanced quite a lot these last years, I don't think Japanese would be that impossible anymore. You risk a few typos, but still.

https://github.com/bluaxees/Poricom/
https://github.com/bluaxees/Cloe/

Wish you luck, this is a series that's been on my backlog for a while, I had plans to just watch it subless eventually, but if you succeed, I'd be interested.

Few years ago I found a Jap movie whose subs were only available in a bluray rip that was 30GB, I got so pissed I typed it all by hand and put it on opensubs, then waited 2 months for someone to seed the 1GB version of the movie on Piratebay and have been seeding it ever since.

I believe all slots were filled, though I don’t have the manual with me. It’s hard to see in the photo, but there are little scuff marks on the solder where it seems it was attached at one point. The problems started after I repasted my CPU and was generally working in that area

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1309516
>>1309524
>I only just noticed the damage.
So you don't even have the allegedly missing capacitor.
If you mean the area I circled in red, I guarantee you there never was a capacitor there.
It's a through-hole footprint, so there would be leads sticking out of the solder pads if a capacitor had been pulled out.

>I don’t have the manual with me
The manual won't tell you whether or not there was a capacitor there, but if you still need confirmation, you can look up your motherboard's model name and look at the pictures on the product page.

>since then I’ve only noticed audio popping and infrequent lag in games
Your problem is caused by something else and you're barking at the wrong tree.

>The problems started after I repasted my CPU and was generally working in that area
I once had weird untraceable problems on one of my computers that right started after I did the same thing.
So I removed the heatsink, and the CPU from the socket, and found that a small smear of thermal paste was covering a few of the pads.
Cleaned that with alcohol and a cotton swab, and put everything back together.
The problems completely went away.

I would say there's a good chance you're experiencing the same thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1309524
>I don’t have the manual with me

Unless you are into hardware repair it's not in the manual. They don't put crap like the hundreds of tiny components and their locations into the user manual they throw in the box.

>>1309516
>Is it worth trying to solder it back on?

If you know the problem and have the skills, the equipment, the parts and the time it's usually always worth doing a small repair job.

But you don't actually know there's a problem with the hardware you just think it. And you don't know what the problem is you just say there were there issues then you claim they are caused by a missing cap. And you don't know what size capacitor it takes or even if it is actually missing a capacitor so you don't have the parts. And if you had the skills I doubt you'd be asking if it was worth an attempt to repair.

So, no. It's not worth risking killing your motherboard over audio popping or infrequent lag which could be caused by any number of software issues let alone appealing to hardware.

And we can't tell you if it will kill your motherboard since we don't know either. Failures from completely broken wires and traces, and in this case a missing cap would be a complete fail open, tend to be instant rather than cumulative. Under and over voltage both cause problems and we don't know which way if any the failure is going if either, or even if there is a failure. So should you keep using it...if you want?

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

I assume you don't have an account, so it is time to Register an account so that you can login to it. At the top of the RO page at:

Once you create your Warp portal account, you can then create login accounts for each game that is run by Warp Portal of which the PC game "Ragnarok Online" is one of them. So, after you are logged into your Warpportal account, you then create a game account login for Ragnarok Online. After you do that, you can then run the RO client and login to the game account.

>>1307409
>>1307750
>Anything really, as long as it just gets the brain working.
>Ideally though I'm looking for less calculator based stuff and more mental maths, the sort that can come up in daily life.
learn how to use basic math to estimate or calculate numbers quickly. for example:
you want to estimate 190x71
190 = 200-10, 71 =70+1

then a quick estimation would be 190x71 ~= 200x70 = 2x7x100x10 = 14000.
for a better estimation, you substract 70x10 = 700, and you get 13300.
you get the final sum if you add 200-10 = 190: 13300 + 190 = 13490
what did I do here? I used the distributive property of addition and multiplication to make the actual calculation easier:
190x71 = (200-10)x(70+1) = 200x70 - 70x10 + 200 - 10


the actual calculation on paper, step by step:
190x71 = (200 - 10) x (70 + 1) = 200x70 + 200x1 - 10x70 - 10x1
= 2x7x100x10 + 200 - 7x100 - 10
= 14x1000 + 200 - 700 - 10
= 14000 - 500 - 10
= 13500 - 10
= 13400 + (100 - 10)
= 13490
this calculation takes many steps, but a quick estimation is far quicker if you know how to do it and are able to keep the numbers in your mind.

how do you use this in real life? say you are paying a bill: you bought 190 items at 71 cents each, and you want a quick estimation of how much it should cost before paying (so you don't get scammed or whatever), then you do this quick mental calculation and are able to estimate the final cost BEFORE paying anything.

posts.com:
>>1308306
>how do I practice this and develop it?
>What are your ways of long division/multiplication anon? On paper, I need to remind myself of the best ways of those too.
these two are the same question, and have the same answer: learn and memorize the properties of the addition, substraction, multiplication and division, then apply them in convenient ways.


using the same example, >>1307851 . notice that I actually did more things than simply using the distributive property of +/*:

>200x70 = 2x7x100x10 = 14000
here, I applied the associative and commutative properties of multiplication to move the zeros to the end so that I could compute the most difficult calculation (2x7) first and then multiply that for 100x10 (which is easier than 2x7), which is not really a multiplication: it's a matter of adding 3 zeros to the right of 14. ask yourself, why do this? answer: to make both the memorization and calculation in my mind easier to myself.

>190x71 = (200 - 10) x (70 + 1)
again, I came with these numbers, ordered them and applied the properties of the operations (addition, multiplication, substraction) in a way I could make it easy to calculate the final result. I could have used other numbers, say:
190x71 = (150 + 40) x (60 + 11)
and it would be the same result with a different path for calculation, and, most importantly, a different difficulty (for me at least, multiplying anything by 11 becomes more difficult).
THAT is the magic of maths: you can use the numbers and its properties in different ways, you can then find the easier path and enf up with the result you want.

see, that multiplication could be made even more difficult:
190x71 = (127 + 33) x (94 - 23)
but, why do this?

get a basic maths book that teachers the properties of the basic operations (addition, multiplication, substraction, division), do its exercises, then practice the above with random numbers and random "pathways".

>>1308994
>>1308990
This is plebian filtering
Picasso was a child prodigy. Was able to reflect reality in the same way 14th-18th century painters of Italy, Germany and the Europes in general. But it was a stagnant position. What do you do when you pretty much win the lottery of artistic merit before you're 18? You start to experiment. He chose to do abstract art, not degenerate over time. The OP pic is an observation of an experimenter over time, not someone going lazy or senile. If you observe more of his abstract art, you see that he has observed from reality and rearranged it in an experimental way.Look at any of Picasso's nude art of women, he knows where to put boobs and how gravity positions them on top of the abdomen, but he exaggerates it to cartoonish lengths. Why? Because he has IRL models pose and he just did what he did
In short, Pablo Picasso learned the rules of art and then broke the rules of art.
I literally can't think of a series, manga or comic, where 1 artist was the lead of the book for multiple decades and he decided to experiment in the series' art style. I can think of books where the art lost volume, perspective, and became stale, but not experimental. But I can think of comic artists who in general embraced experimentalism. Kyle Baker in the 80s had a more combination of newspaper cartoon and semi realism, then by the 2000s it became exteremely versatile, 3d models, 2d cartoon symbol art, and exaggerated proportions on realistic rendered people

posts.com: which program should I use to create and edit .mkv files?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1309053
Handbrake or MKVToolNix.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1309053
Any video editor you like. If it doesn't support the mkv container and/or the streams contained in the mkv you'll need to

Convert the container to a supported container, e.g. mp4, mov, avi, etc. which are commonly supported containers in many editors
and/or
demux the streams
and/or
convert the streams into supported streams, e.g for video h.265/x265, h.264/x264, mpeg-1/2, etc. and for audio aac, mp3, wav, etc.

import and edit them,

export them as one or more streams in one or more containers

mux them to an mkv container


mkvtoolnix as other anon suggested can handle the demuxing and muxing which is a lossless operation. Handbrake can convert many streams but transcoding is a lossy operation.
Bear in mind that mkv is a container. It doesn't tell you about the content type and it is famous for holding many different types of streams.

If any of the above doesn't make sense chances are it's more that you need to question why you want to create mkv files than that I made an error.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I recently bought a 50W Valve Amp, it works great most of the time, except I live in bumfuck nowhere and the tension/power stability of my electrical system leaves much to be desired.
Lights dim whenever I turn on the oven, Wi-Fi Repeater turns off when I use a vacuum cleaner etc. I never cared, but as soon as I brought the amp home I noticed that during these moments, my amp's volume plummets as soon as the lights dim and comes back when the tension drop stops. Is this dangerous for my power amp valves? Will a UPS system solve this problem? Please help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In theory, it should be the voltage spikes that damage equipment, not the voltage drops. I would expect your amp to have a protective circuit for spikes as well, but you can never know what can go wrong. A UPS would definitely solve the voltage drop issues and prevent any damage from potential spikes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1309234
> " Is this dangerous for my power amp valves? ..." ;
No - the fluctuations you describe are a drop of supply voltage. Valves are more likely to fail at initial power up (i.e. turning the valve amp on) when the sudden increase of filament temperature can cause filament burn out,
or a "power surge" when the supply voltage suddenly increases e.g. due to electromagnetic induction, when another piece of unsurpressed high power equipment is turned off, in close proximity.

> "... Will a UPS system solve this problem? " ;
I was going to suggest that as a realistic solution (if you hadn't already suggested it)
I think it would be reasonable to buy one off Amazon, and in the event that it doesn't solve your audio problem, return it for a full refund as being unsuitable for your needs.

posts.com: which way do i turn the screws on the back of the japanese n64 cartridge to take it off? am retard. i have the screw driver needed for it but ive been fiddling it and i worry i might break it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1309149
They're right-handed screws, just like most screws.
Take your right hand and stick your thumb up, away from the screw.
The direction of the other fingers is the direction of the spin.
If you want to drive the screw in instead, stick your thumb toward the screw.
Works with nuts and valves too, in any orientation.

There's not much danger of turning the screws the wrong way because the head flat underneath, so it just bottoms out against the plastic.

TL;DR Counter-clockwise

Firstly, please don't reuse variable names and function names. L36 throws you an error since you declared geinstantce as an integer array when you are trying to call it as a function.
You also need to understand scoping. In C, a variable can only be accessed within the function/block it was declared in. From your code, the variable w only exists inside the function getinstantce. As a result, when you try to access w, the compiler throws an error that w is undeclared.
When you call a function, you must give the necessary parameters. From the function declaration on L11, getinstatce must have 3 parameters the: array, size, and threshold. So, when you call getinstantce, you must provide the necessary parameters. e.g. getinstantce(array, 3, 7);
As for the optimization of the two for loops, it should be possible to combine them. Just set *w to the first element of the array and do the comparisons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1308925
>I dont get why the function works when we pass different names for the array into it (i_arr instead if the instance_array) is res basically saying I am inputting these values into the function, and the function is saying I am taking those values but changing the name (if I so desire)

There's 3 things going on here: values, variables, and variable addresses. tl;dr The variables in your function are not the same as the variables in main.


Suppose you have a shelf, a box, and a notepad. When you say "int s=4;" you've taken a box, written "s" on the front of it in big black sharpie, and put 4 things in it. Box goes on the shelf, and behind the scenes, you write down which shelf it's on, in the notepad. You then repeat this for "v" and "w", and each one gets a big letter on the front, something inside it, and an entry in your notepad. (Don't worry about the array for now.)

The variable is the box. The thing inside the box is the value. The entry on your notepad is the address. So far, so good. https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cprogramming/c_pointers.htm


Now, you want to call get_instance. It expects 4 arguments: an int pointer to an array (don't worry about it for now), two ints, and an int pointer. So you call your friend over. She comes over with four completely different boxes, with different names written on them. Her first says "i_arr", her second says "s", her third says "v", and her fourth says "w". But they're COMPLETELY different boxes, and she can write whatever she wants on them.

Your boxes are the variables in main. Her boxes are the variables in get_instance. Your boxes only exist in main, and her boxes only exist in get_instance. This is variable scope. https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cprogramming/c_scope_rules.htm

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1308925
>also for int res I dont get why we have &w(I know its pointer notation) is making it a pointer what allows me to change the value? I feel like I understand pointers a little, but when we throw functions into the mix I get more confused. Can you explain it or give me links to material that can explain it? When I watch videos on just pointers or just functions I am fine, but when I watch the videos on both of them I just get confused with their examples.

tl;dr &w doesn't pass the variable, it passes the address.


You start showing your friend your boxes, in the exact order you provided. The array is first, but we'll skip that. Next, you pick up your "s" box and show it to her; she counts the number of things in there, and then puts that many things in her "s" box. You put yours back on your shelf when she's done. Your "s" box is unchanged, and nothing that she takes out of or puts into her "s" box will affect yours. You do the same for "v". This is "pass by value". https://www.tutorialspoint.com/what-is-pass-by-value-in-c-language

When she gets to her fourth box though, she sees you didn't give her "w", you gave her "&w". The special syntax of the ampersand means that you don't show her the value in w, you show her your notepad instead. So, instead of counting what's in your "w" box and putting it in hers, she copies what you wrote in your notebook for "w", rips that paper out of her notebook, and puts it in her "w" box instead, then makes a little * so she knows to treat it special. Whenever she wants to make a change to her "w" box, that * tells her to take a special action: she'll pick up the paper, walk to your "w" box, and change it there. She doesn't truly have a "w" variable of her own to change, just instructions on how to find yours. Don't worry, she doesn't mind walking back and forth. This is "pass by reference". https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cprogramming/c_function_call_by_reference.htm

>as for scoping I am assuming the w could only be called because we passed it in the function? or is it because the pointer the main w referenced went away when the function ended?

tl;dr You could modify main's w because get_instance had a reference to it. References and pointers are different, but allow you to perform similar tasks.


Both you and your friend have a box for each of your variables, and those boxes are your own. When she is done with her work, she returns one thing to you in a new box called "return", and then throws the rest of her boxes out - anything inside of them is lost and you have no way to know what the contents were. Her "v" is lost, and her "s" is lost. What about "w"? She never had the real box, only the address to it. She loses her copy of the address, but you've still got "w" safe and sound in your function. https://www.tutorialspoint.com/pointers-vs-references-in-cplusplus

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1308955
>C technically does not have "pass by reference"
Neither does C++. It only passes by value, but you can pass references by value just like in C.

C++ has no equivalent of true pass-by-reference (like in, for example, Pascal), where the function/method signature can mark a parameter as "by reference", and if you call it, the variable you use in that parameter can have a different value after the function returns. You can fake pass-by-reference with mutable objects or by manually passing in a pointer, but C++ does not have pass-by-reference.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1308959
You are correct on both.
"*w" is C's way of saying "There is an address in this variable, so go look up the address and then make any changes there.
If you create some variable "w" in a function, and some variable "w" in main, they are completely different variables that just happen to have the same name. They live in different places, and even if they both DID somehow exist at the same time, a function can't see variables outside its current scope.

Standard practice varies between individuals and teams, but for now, I'd recommend getting into the habit of giving variables descriptive names that clearly indicate what they do. Pretty much everyone does that!

For the sake of the analogy, in pass by reference, there is no "copy" - there is only the original, and the address where you can find it. When you say " *w = 5; " you aren't making changes to a local w that get reflected on the original, you are going to the original w and changing it there.
" & " means "give the address to the variable"
" * " means "this variable holds an address, follow it back and use that original"

>>1309027
here's the content of the script

function load(url, element)
{
req = new XMLHttpRequest();
req.open("GET", url, false);
req.send(null);

element.innerHTML = req.responseText;
}

load("operation.php", document.getElementById("text"));
